Class: Router

Router

The Router is used to determine which page object should be used by the test. If can either look up a page object based on the url or set a page object based on a parameter passed along from the test. The router instantiates a new pageObject as page and returns page as an available class with context-specific methods.

new Router()

A Router class handles context driven decisions for the test suite.

Source:
  • router.js, line 4

Methods

<static> getContext() → {Object}

Determines which page object to use

Uses if/else logic with regular expressions to determine the current page base on matching parts of the current url. A matching condition instantiates the corresponding page and returns a page object.

Source:
  • router.js, line 13
Returns:

A page object

Type
Object
Example
//step.js
    _page = new login_page();
    console.log(_page) // outputs: login_page{}
    browser.url('home.e2ma.net'); // Navigates to https://home.myemma.com
    console.log(_page) // outputs: login_page{}
    Router.getContext(); // Looks up page based on current url
    console.log(_page) // outputs: home_page{}

<static> setContext(targetPage) → {Object}

Returns a new Page Object matching the {targetPage} parameter

Use when trying to force a Page Object onto a test without comparing url's

Parameters:
Name Type Description
targetPage String

The intended page
Source:
  • router.js, line 52
Returns:

A page object that matches targetPage.

Type
Object
Example
//step.js
    _page = new login_page();
    console.log(_page) // outputs: login_page{}
    Router.setContext('home')
    console.log(_page) // outputs: home_page{}

<static> switchPage(targetPage) → {Object}

Change from one page object to another inside a test

Compares current url (from selenium) with destination url (from page object). If they do not match, it sets page to the the corresponding targetPage, navigates to it via url, and then returns the page object.

Parameters:
Name Type Description
targetPage String

The intended page
Source:
  • router.js, line 94
Returns:

A page object that matches targetPage.

Type
Object
Example
//step.js
    _page = new login_page();
    console.log(_page) // outputs: login_page{}
    _page = router.switchPage('home')
    console.log(_page) // outputs: home_page{}
